text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: AUGUST 2019
label: BODY

text: WHAT IS A DATA INCIDENT IN HUMANITARIAN RESPONSE?
label: BODY

text: In the humanitarian sector, data incidents are events involving the management of data that have caused
label: BODY

text: harm or have the potential to cause harm to crisis affected populations, humanitarian organisations
label: BODY

text: and their operations, and other individuals or groups. These events can exploit or exacerbate existing
label: BODY

text: vulnerabilities.1 In some cases, they may also create new vulnerabilities that can increase the risk of future
label: BODY

text: data incidents.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarians have not had a common understanding of what comprises a data incident, nor is there
label: BODY

text: a minimum technical standard for how these incidents should be prevented and managed. How the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian sector develops tools and implements procedures for data incident management will play
label: BODY

text: a significant role in the evolution of the ethical, human rights, technical, and professional standards of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian operations.
label: BODY

text: 1     “A vulnerability is a weakness in an information system, system security procedures, internal controls, or implementation that could be exploited by
label: BODY

text: a threat source.” NIST Special Publication 800-30 Revision 1, Guide for Conducting Risk Assessments.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: GUIDANCE NOTE SERIES
label: HH2

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH3

text: DATA INCIDENT MANAGEMENT
label: HH1

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH2

text: •	 Humanitarian data incidents are events involving the management of data that have caused
label: BODY

text: harm or have the potential to cause harm to crisis-affected people, organizations and their
label: BODY

text: operations, and other individuals or groups.
label: BODY

text: •	 Examples of humanitarian data incidents include physical breaches of infrastructure,
label: BODY

text: unauthorised disclosure of data, and the use of beneficiary data for non-humanitarian purposes,
label: BODY

text: among others.
label: BODY

text: •	 A data incident has four aspects: (i) a threat source, (ii) a threat event, (iii) a vulnerability and (iv)
label: BODY

text: an adverse impact.
label: BODY

text: •	 There are five steps to responding to data incidents: (i) notification, (ii) classification, (iii)
label: BODY

text: treatment, and (iv) closure of the incident, as well as (v) learning.
label: BODY

text: “If aid actors digitize more of their data and communications, they urgently
label: BODY

text: need to increase their digital security efforts. Though some actors are
label: BODY

text: developing promising protective tools, aid organizations overall might be
label: BODY

text: well advised to listen to a quote from IT-security circles: ‘There are two
label: BODY

text: types of organizations: those who have been hacked, and those who will be.”
label: BODY

text: - Rahel Dette, Do No Digital Harm: Mitigating Technology Risk in Humanitarian Contexts
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: AUGUST 2019
label: BODY

text: DEFINITIONS AND FRAMEWORKS FOR UNDERSTANDING DATA INCIDENTS
label: HH3

text: Governments and the private sector have developed definitions and frameworks for understanding data
label: BODY

text: incidents that serve as helpful references for the humanitarian sector.
label: BODY

text: •	 The International Organization for Standardization’s (ISO) in ISO Standard 27000 defines a ‘critical
label: BODY

text: incident’ as “a single or a series of unwanted or unexpected information security events that have a
label: BODY

text: significant probability of compromising business operations and threatening information security.”2
label: BODY

text: •	 The United States Department of Commerce National Institute for Standards and Technology (NIST)
label: BODY

text: defines an adverse event involving a ‘cyber threat’ as “[a]n event or condition that has the potential
label: BODY

text: for causing asset loss and the undesirable consequences or impact from such loss.”3
label: BODY

text: •	 Mahmood Sher-Jan of the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP) identifies three
label: BODY

text: additional categories of events that expand upon the NIST definition of adverse events. These are, in
label: BODY

text: order of escalating severity: security incidents; privacy incidents; and data breaches.4
label: BODY

text: 2     International Organization for Standardization, ISO/IEC 27000:2018.
label: BODY

text: 3     NIST Computer Security Resource Center Glossary.
label: BODY

text: 4     IAPP, Is It an Incident or a Breach, How to Tell and Why It Matters, Mahmoud Sher-Jan (February 2017).
label: BODY

text: 5     NIST Special Publication 800-30 Revision 1, Guide for Conducting Risk Assessments.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian data incidents may include physical breaches of infrastructure, unauthorised disclosure of
label: BODY

text: data, and the use of ‘anonymised’ beneficiary data for non-humanitarian purposes, among others. Data
label: BODY

text: incidents can also occur without technical infrastructure being compromised in any way. The legitimate
label: BODY

text: collection, use, and sharing of data by humanitarians can still have operational implications that may
label: BODY

text: constitute a data incident in cases where rumors, cultural sensitivities, political dynamics, and other
label: BODY

text: factors lead to adverse effects linked to the data.
label: BODY

text: Examples of possible humanitarian data incidents
label: BODY

text: A data incident has four factors: a threat source, a threat event, a vulnerability and an adverse impact.5
label: BODY

text: Below are two types of hypothetical data incidents that could occur in humanitarian contexts.
label: BODY

text: The first scenario is a typical data breach incident situated in the context of an armed conflict. The
label: BODY

text: second is an example of the type of vulnerabilities that can initiate data incidents unique to the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian sector.
label: BODY

text: 1.	Unauthorized access to data occurs [impact] due to armed actors [source] raiding a facility and
label: BODY

text: seizing hard-drives containing beneficiary data [event]. The hard-drives were unencrypted
label: BODY

text: [vulnerability].
label: BODY

text: 2.	Absence of guidance limiting data collection for a specific purpose [vulnerability] leads to staff
label: BODY

text: collecting data about the marital status of pregnant women [source]. A data breach [event] later
label: BODY

text: occurs, resulting in an increased chance of physical violence [impact] against unwed pregnant
label: BODY

text: beneficiaries.
label: BODY

text: These scenarios demonstrate how to think about identifying causal chains that may create context-
label: BODY

text: specific data incidents.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: AUGUST 2019
label: BODY

text: 6    NIST Special Publication 800-30 Revision 1, Guide for Conducting Risk Assessments.
label: BODY

text: RISK MODELS
label: HH3

text: The figure below presents a generic risk model with risk factors that organizations can use to understand
label: BODY

text: how a data incident may occur. A threat event exploits an existing vulnerability that is either magnified by
label: BODY

text: predisposing conditions or mitigated by security controls already in place. This causes adverse impacts that
label: BODY

text: produce organizational risk, which can include risks for the organization and for affected people.
label: BODY

text: Figure 1. “Generic Risk Model with Key Risk Factors”. Source: NIST Special Publication
label: BODY

text: The figure below presents one example of how this generic risk model could be adapted to the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian sector.
label: BODY

text: Figure 2. Risk Model with Key Risk Factors adapted to a humanitarian context.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: AUGUST 2019
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations can develop their own specific risk models for data incident management
label: BODY

text: incorporating these factors. The nature of these risk factors and how they come together to constitute a
label: BODY

text: data incident will vary from one organization to another and should be adapted to specific operational
label: BODY

text: realities.
label: BODY

text: STEPS IN DATA INCIDENT MANAGEMENT
label: HH2

text: After clearly defining what constitutes a data incident, organizations can develop Standard Operating
label: BODY

text: Procedures (SOPs) for data incident management.
label: BODY

text: Data incident management SOPs should include the following 5 steps: 1) notification,  2) classification;
label: BODY

text: 3) treatment;  4) closure; and 5) knowledge base.7
label: BODY

text: 7    The Centre for Humanitarian Data provides several sources of guidance that can inform the development of Data Incident Management SOPs on
label: BODY

text: the Data Responsibility page.
label: BODY

text: 8    How to handle incidents according to ISO 27001 A.16, Antonio Jose Segovia, (October 2015.).
label: BODY

text: 9    For humanitarian organizations, an example of such a classification is the World Health Organization’s (WHO) International Classification of
label: BODY

text: Patient Safety, Conceptual Framework for the International Classification of Patient Safety.
label: BODY

text: 10 WHO, Conceptual Framework for the International Classification of Patient Safety.
label: BODY

text: Figure 3: Five steps in the treatment of security incidents (Source: How to handle incidents according to ISO 27001 A.16,
label: BODY

text: Antonio Jose Segovia8
label: BODY

text: The application of these steps in an organization can look as follows:
label: BODY

text: 1.	Notification of the incident: A person detects an incident and notifies relevant colleagues according
label: HH3

text: to the communication procedures of the organization (usually an email, a phone call, a software tool,
label: BODY

text: etc.). A notification should contain, if possible, a description of the key risk factors involved in the
label: BODY

text: incident: source, event, vulnerability and impact.
label: BODY

text: 2.	Classification of the incident: The recipient of the notification classifies the incident based on it’s
label: HH3

text: impact (high, medium or low) and the urgency of treatment (high, medium or low).9 Managing risk
label: BODY

text: begins with classifying all incidents, whether or not tangible harm actually results from them.10
label: BODY

text: 3.	Treatment of the incident: A technical expert decides on the necessary measures to treat the incident
label: HH3

text: once the incident has been classified and the time for treatment has been agreed.
label: BODY

text: 4.	Closure of the incident: All information generated during the treatment is recorded and the person
label: HH3

text: who first sent notification of the incident is informed that the incident is closed.
label: BODY

text: 5.	Knowledge base: All information generated during the treatment of the incident is used to inform and
label: HH3

text: train colleagues and as reference material for future similar incidents.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations can base their SOPs on this 5-step model, describing how each step should
label: BODY

text: take place within their organization. This should include the functions/roles and teams within an
label: BODY

text: organization that are responsible at each stage of the process. These steps should be incorporated into
label: BODY

text: or extended from existing incident response protocols (e.g. security incident management related to
label: BODY

text: humanitarian access).
label: BODY

text: In a given response context, organizations should also work to integrate any joint incident management
label: BODY

text: procedures into existing coordination structures, such as the clusters and mechanisms for inter- and
label: BODY

text: intra-cluster coordination.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: AUGUST 2019
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVING DATA INCIDENT MANAGEMENT IN
label: HH3

text: HUMANITARIAN ORGANIZATIONS
label: HH3

text: Introducing or improving data incident management in humanitarian operations is critical to more
label: BODY

text: responsible data practice in the sector. The Centre for Humanitarian Data recommends that organizations
label: BODY

text: focus on the following areas:
label: BODY

text: 1.	Establish a common understanding of data incident management
label: HH3

text: Use a risk model to understand the causal chain that can lead to data incidents for specific offices and
label: BODY

text: systems. Identify key threat actors and vulnerabilities for offices and systems and understand existing
label: BODY

text: security controls and their effectiveness. Finally, map existing data incident management capacity
label: BODY

text: and determine whether it is positioned appropriately. Once clear definitions and processes are
label: BODY

text: articulated, invest in staff awareness and support a culture of open dialogue about incidents, in which
label: BODY

text: proactive reporting and management of incidents is incentivized, not punished.
label: BODY

text: 2.	Strengthen data incident management capacity
label: HH3

text: Take measures to put in place security controls to mitigate the risk of data incidents, and share best
label: BODY

text: practice with partners. Build on existing work in the sector to fill governance gaps which can create
label: BODY

text: vulnerabilities for your organization. Engage with organizational partners to set up information
label: BODY

text: channels around data incidents. Share known vulnerabilities in a controlled manner with trusted
label: BODY

text: counterparts for cross-organizational learning.
label: BODY

text: 3.	Support continuous learning
label: HH3

text: Support learning and development of improved data incident management practices by organizing
label: BODY

text: training and drills based on scenarios likely to occur in different operational settings. These exercises
label: BODY

text: should occur regularly and may even involve multiple organizations training and drilling together. In
label: BODY

text: addition, document actual data incidents as cases for internal knowledge development.
label: BODY

text: Organizations are encouraged to share their experience in the development of data incident management
label: BODY

text: with the Centre for Humanitarian Data via centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: COLLABORATORS: YALE UNIVERSITY, JACKSON INSTITUTE OF GLOBAL AFFAIRS.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’), together with key partners, is publishing a series of eight
label: BODY

text: guidance notes on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2019 and 2020. The Guidance
label: BODY

text: Note series follows the publication of the OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines in March 2019. Through
label: BODY

text: the series, the Centre aims to provide additional guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in practice. This series is made possible with the generous support of the Directorate-General for
label: BODY

text: European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO).
label: BODY
